The 71-year-old won 60.75% of the vote while his nearest rival Kizza Besigye took 35%, the election commission has announced. The 71-year-old, President Yoweri Museveni, has retained his position as the head of Uganda, following a contentious election. The victory has extended his rule into a fourth decade, with this marking his sixth term in office.

The election results saw Museveni securing 60.75% of the vote, while his closest competitor, Kizza Besigye, garnered 35%. This was a significant win for Museveni, who managed to maintain a substantial lead over his main rival. 

However, the election was not without controversy, with Besigye's supporters alleging widespread voter fraud and irregularities. Besigye himself was arrested multiple times during the election period, raising questions about the fairness of the elections. 

Despite these disturbances, international observers have noted that aside from isolated incidents, the elections were generally peaceful. 

The election commission’s announcement has paved the way for Museveni to continue his long-standing rule. Whether this will bring stability or

original:
Palmer expects to be fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for the rule breach during Champions Day. "It was a regrettable error on my part," the veteran trainer admitted, and expects to face financial repercussions after falling foul of BHA's regulations on Champions Day.

The infraction occurred when Palmer, renowned in the horseracing world for his numerous victories, ran an ineligible horse in one of the day's most prestigious races. Despite Palmer's pleas for leniency, citing a simple misunderstanding of the rules, the BHA is committed to maintaining the integrity of the sport.

A spokesperson from the BHA affirmed, "While we appreciate Mr. Palmer's honesty in this matter, a breach in rules cannot be overlooked. Ensuring fair competition for all participants is our utmost priority."

Whilst the exact amount of the fine is yet to be determined, some speculate it could potentially reach into the thousands, significantly affecting Palmer's earnings from Champions Day. Despite the setback, Palmer remains optimistic about his future in the sport, promising to ensure compliance with all BHA regulations going forward.

original: Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. Rossouw, in his first season in county cricket, refused to say if his hand had been forced by Cricket South Africa. "Maybe, maybe not," he told BBC Sport. "I think that story is one I'm going to tell at a different time." Kolpak contracts allow sportsmen from countries with associate trade agreements with the European Union to be afforded the same right to free movement as EU citizens. They are not classed as overseas players under the terms of their contracts, but they become ineligible to represent their country at international level. Abbott and Rossouw's decisions came before Britain's exit from the European Union and they are among several South Africans to make the switch ahead of the new domestic season. Among the others, all-rounder Simon Harmer has joined Essex,Stiaan van Zyl and David Wiese have moved to Sussex and fast bowler Hardus Viljoen will line up for Derbyshire.

original:
Mr Reagan and three others were injured in the shooting outside a hotel in Washington in March 1981. Mr Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity and has lived in a psychiatric hospital since the assassination attempt on the then-president.

Mr Reagan and three others were injured in the shooting outside a hotel in Washington in March 1981. Mr Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity and has lived in a psychiatric hospital since the assassination attempt on the then-president. He opened fire as Ronald Reagan was leaving the Washington Hilton Hotel after a conference, seriously wounding the president and three others. 

The shooting shocked the nation and brought into sharp focus the issue of gun control and mental health. Hinckley, obsessed with actress Jodie Foster and seeking to impress her, was committed to St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington. His release in 2016, after more than three decades, was met with widespread controversy, renewing debates on mental health, gun control, and the adequacy of the insanity defense. The incident remains one of the most notorious in American political history.

original: Envoy Sigrid Kaag was speaking as Syria appeared to miss a Sunday deadline to remove its arsenal from the country. All Syria's chemical weapons were supposed to have been shipped out by February 5th, but a failure to meet this deadline has led to growing international concern. Envoy Sigrid Kaag, who heads the joint mission of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and the United Nations, voiced her concerns about the delay. She reiterated that the international community is closely watching the situation. "This is not a deadline to be missed lightly," Kaag said. "Every delay increases the risk of these weapons falling into the wrong hands, with unthinkable consequences." As the deadline passed, only around 11% of Syria's chemical arsenal had been removed, according to the OPCW. The international community is calling on Syria to accelerate the process. The delay not only puts the disarmament process at risk but also underscores the complexity and challenges of eliminating Syria's sizable chemical weapons program amidst an ongoing civil war.

"Missing this deadline is serious," Kaag said. "Each delay heightens the risk of these weapons ending up in dangerous hands, with dire consequences." By the deadline, only about 11% of Syria's chemical weapons had been removed, per OPCW reports. The international community urges Syria to speed up the removal. The delay jeopardizes the disarmament effort and highlights the challenges of dismantling Syria's chemical weapons amid ongoing conflict.

original: The Port Talbot-based Specific innovation centre is working on the concept of "buildings as power stations". The project involves Tata Steel, Swansea and Cardiff universities, and firms including BASF and Pilkington. More than half the funding is from the European Union. The technology being developed aims to enable homes, offices, shops and factories to generate, store and use their own solar energy. It involves creating innovative coatings for roofs, walls, steel and glass on buildings which can generate electricity. Scientists are also developing solar air collectors or steel "skins" which create cavities between the heated metal and the building to harness and store solar heat. They hope to create buildings which will not need a gas supply. One industrial unit in Port Talbot has already been generating all its own heat through solar power for the last three years. Kevin Bygate, chief executive of Specific said the potential was to deliver a "game changer" on energy: not only for buildings to become self-sufficient but for surplus energy to be stored and to supply the grid. They were close to reaching a target

original: Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) said the force had "fragile" staffing levels and needed to "implement improvement plans rapidly". Inspectors visited the force after criticising its response to government spending cuts last year. Police and Crime Commissioner Olly Martins said the report was "out of date". In the HMIC's Policing in Austerity: Meeting the Challenge report last year, Bedfordshire Police was judged to be "requiring improvement". Inspectors, who said the force would be "monitored closely", returned in October and found it was not performing well compared to similar forces. It highlighted problems in the force control room, although said these should be improved by a recent increase in staff. The report described staffing levels as "fragile but improving" and said although there had been recruitment, it was not clear what investment the force had made in preventive work to reduce demand. "There is a concern that it may not be tackling longer-term issues," the report said. Inspectors said it needed to implement its plans for improving policing in "an affordable way more quickly" while ensuring its service "remains effective". However, they

original:
The amnesty applies to offences committed during the political turmoil after Mr Thaksin was ousted in a coup. The lower house passed the controversial bill in a late-night voting session, further polarizing the already divided nation. 

Opponents of the initiative argue that it is a thinly veiled attempt by the government to whitewash the crimes of exiled former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, allowing him to return without facing corruption charges. Proponents, however, claim the legislation is a crucial step towards healing the deep wounds of the political crisis that has gripped the country for over a decade.

The bill has sparked mass protests in the capital, Bangkok, with thousands taking to the streets in opposition. It is a move that is likely to exacerbate the political instability that has plagued Thailand since the 2006 military coup.

original:
Helen Bailey, 51, was found dead in a cess pit at her house in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016. She had been reported missing three months prior, sparking a large-scale manhunt. The renowned author of the Electra Brown series, she was known to have touched the hearts of many young readers worldwide. The gruesome discovery sparked a media frenzy around the usually serene Royston community.

Upon further investigation, the police identified her partner, Ian Stewart, as the primary suspect. The evidence pointed to an intricately planned act, resulting in the arrest and subsequent conviction of Stewart for her murder.

The shocking incident has left the literary world in utter disbelief, and sadness permeates among her readers worldwide. Helen's death is a tragic reminder of the hidden dangers that can exist behind seemingly normal lives. Bailey's legacy, however, continues to live on through her engaging and relatable characters, even as her untimely death remains a horrifying mystery.

original: New shots of Charlene Downes, 14, who was last seen in Blackpool town centre, were discovered during a trawl of CCTV. Her body has never been found. Her mother Karen said she was "disgusted" the footage had only just been found after years spent investigating the unsolved murder case. Lancashire Police said it "understood" Ms Downes' views. Nobody has been convicted over Charlene's death. The footage has been released on the anniversary of Charlene's 2003 disappearance - as part of the forces "longest" murder investigation. The charity wants 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by civil war to be resettled by the end of the year. Ahead of an anticipated spike in displacement caused by escalating violence, the charity is calling for a significant increase in global resettlement efforts for Syrian refugees. This ambitious target, if met, would mark a considerable improvement in the current state of affairs for the estimated 4.8 million Syrians forced from their homes due to the ongoing conflict. 

The charity's goal is not merely to provide temporary relief for these refugees, but to offer them a chance at rebuilding their lives in a safe and secure environment. These resettlement efforts would involve cooperation and support from governments worldwide. Despite the myriad challenges such a goal presents, the charity remains undeterred, viewing this as an imperative, humanitarian duty.

The charity's appeal comes at a time when the world is grappling with the worst refugee crisis since World War II. With this bold initiative, they hope to bring attention to the plight of Syrian refugees and inspire action on a global scale to address this crisis.

Gabon was selected as host on Wednesday by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee, beating rival candidates Ghana and Algeria. "We will prepare meticulously to present a first-class tournament," a Gabonese government spokesperson said, expressing the country's commitment to making the event a resounding success. 

This decision marks a significant win for Gabon, who now holds the responsibility of showcasing African football to the world. Preparation efforts will focus on upgrading infrastructures, enhancing security measures, and improving sporting facilities. The competition is expected to boost Gabon's economy by attracting international tourists and promoting local businesses.

The selection of Gabon as the host has received mixed reactions. While some praise it as an opportunity to spotlight the country's growth and potential, others express concern over its readiness to manage such a large-scale event. Nevertheless, the country is determined to rise to the occasion and deliver a memorable tournament. This event will undoubtedly put Gabon on the global sports map and strengthen unity throughout Africa.

A website polled users as to which country he should tour next, with no restrictions on the nations that could be voted on. There are now almost 160 countries listed in the poll's results, reflecting the global outreach and diversity of the website's audience.

The poll is gaining significant attention, with thousands of people worldwide casting their votes. The leading contenders are currently Japan, Australia, and Italy, demonstrating a varied interest in both Eastern and Western cultures. But less travelled nations such as Bhutan, Malawi, and Uzbekistan are also getting impressive votes, highlighting a thirst for off-beat destinations.

This online poll is an interesting way to perceive global tourism preferences, and it provides insight into the diverse tastes and travel dreams of internet users worldwide. As the poll continues to gather votes, it will be exciting to see which destination eventually takes the lead in this global travel wish-list.

original: Disguised as police, they broke through a fence on Monday evening and broke into the cargo of a Swiss-bound plane to take the gems, estimated to be worth $50m (Â£32m; 37m euros). They escaped back through the same hole. Police later found a burned-out vehicle close to the airport. Police are looking for eight men, a prosecutors' spokeswoman said. Caroline De Wolf, of the Antwerp World Diamond Centre, estimated the haul at $50m, saying: "What we are talking about is obviously a gigantic sum." Earlier reports suggested the figure was even higher - with the Belgian state broadcaster reportedly putting it at 350m euros ($468m). AFP quoted an unnamed spokeswoman at the same Antwerp centre calling the robbery "one of the biggest" ever. She said that the diamonds were "rough stones" being transported from Antwerp to Zurich. original:
John McCormack drove for a further 30 miles in the articulated lorry after hitting a vehicle on the A9. Perth Sheriff Court was told there that McCormack, 45, was unaware of the incident due to the size of his vehicle. The incident occurred near the town of Pitlochry in the Scottish Highlands, causing serious damage to the impacted car but leaving its driver uninjured.

The court heard that McCormack only became aware of the accident hours later when he stopped at a service station and noticed the damage to his lorry. McCormack, of Inverness, pleaded guilty to failing to stop and report an accident. Defence solicitor, Mr. David Sinclair argued that McCormack genuinely had no idea that he had hit another car.

The case raises concerns about visibility and awareness for drivers of large vehicles. Sheriff Lindsay Foulis deferred sentence until next month for reports and granted McCormack bail in the meantime. This incident has highlighted the need for improved safety measures and enhanced driver

original: Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their break-up. Andrew Bayne, 37, of Trundleys Terrace, and his nephew Michael Bagnall, 22, of Hospital Way - both in Lewisham - were found guilty of the murder. They will be sentenced at the Old Bailey on 20 November. The court heard Mr Purdy and two of his friends - Callum Malone and Jack Walker - confronted Bagnell, and, following the "skirmish" last November, the defendants drove around Bermondsey looking for Mr Purdy. When they found him in Mossington Gardens, Andrew Bayne shot Mr Purdy in the head then pointed the gun towards Callum before making off. Mr Purdy suffered "catastrophic injuries" and died the next day, the court heard. Despite the fact Bagnall had a new girlfriend, prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC told jurors, it still "rankled" that she had moved on and he sent her "threatening messages" by phone and on Facebook. Mr Aylett said: "Ben obviously had enough

original: Hanjin filed for receivership in South Korea last week after attempts to bail out the indebted company failed. Ports have refused to accept Hanjin cargoes without guarantees that port fees will be paid. However, creditors, banks and the South Korean government are all reluctant to put up the cash. The global economic downturn, fierce competition and falling prices has hit profits across the cargo shipping industry and Hanjin collapsed with debts of about $5.4bn (Â£4.1bn) last month. There are an estimated 89 Hanjin ships out of its 141-vessel fleet in difficulty, and some have been seized by creditors. The ships contain everything from computer parts to perishable food with many of the cargoes destined for the Christmas market in the US and Europe. Samsung Electronics has said it has goods worth about $38m on Hanjin ships in international waters. It is now considering chartering 16 freighter planes to take goods to customers - mostly in the US. Hanjin's main creditors said it would be difficult to accept a request from the court presiding over the company's receivership to give it fresh funds. The state-backed Korea Development Bank said

original:
The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, one of the country's most active, has seen a significant upsurge in activity in recent months, raising concerns among scientists about a potential major eruption. 

The University of Bristol team, in collaboration with colleagues at the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre, have been monitoring the volcano closely. They warn that the current increase in activity could potentially lead to a large-scale eruption, threatening the nearby city of Kagoshima and its 600,000 inhabitants.

The researchers' concerns are built on a combination of seismic data, ground deformation and gas emission measurements. In particular, the alarming rate of ground swelling around the volcano indicates a significant increase in magma supply. 

While the local authorities are taking necessary precautions, the situation serves as a reminder of the unpredictable and devastating power of nature. The current escalation at Sakurajima underscores the urgent

original:
The girl, who has Smith-Magenis Syndrome, was arrested four times and twice held overnight in police stations. Her mother complained about her daughter's treatment, igniting a conversation about the handling of individuals with mental health disorders in the criminal justice system.

Smith-Magenis Syndrome is a developmental disorder that can lead to behavioral issues, including temper tantrums and self-harm. In this case, the young girl's interaction with the police was a result of such behaviors. Her mother, however, insists that the police's response was both excessive and inappropriate. 

The arrests have sparked considerable outrage within the community and beyond, highlighting the broader issue of how law enforcement deals with individuals suffering from mental health disorders. Critics argue that police should be better trained to handle such situations, ensuring that individuals with conditions like Smith-Magenis Syndrome are treated fairly and with compassion. 

This case serves as a stark reminder of the dire need for reform within law enforcement, and for a more empathetic approach to policing

original: Officers at first did not treat Stephen Phillips's death as suspicious after he was found in his Wolverhampton flat. His family became suspicious when they found two mobile phones were missing. Tests proved he had been struck before he fell. Lewis Thornton, 24, has been jailed for 10 years for Mr Phillips' manslaughter and robbery. Mr Phillips, aged, 54 and a father of six, died from a head injury on 11 March 2015 at his home in Dudley Road, Blakenhall. original: The Employment and Learning minister, Dr Stephen Farry, has decided to remove a special premium payment of Â£1.1m which it has been getting to compensate for its small scale and specialist status. It has fewer than 1,000 students and an income of Â£4.7m a year. Protesters have said that the removal of the small institution premium, coupled with a general cutback in Department of Employment and Learning (DEL) funding, would mean the college loses 31% of its budget. However, an extra Â£32m for the DEL, revealed in this week's overall budget improves the situation somewhat. The college says the addition of extra money means it would be asked to manage on a budget reduced by 26.5%. That's a slightly better prediction but the principal, Prof Peter Finn, says that is still far too challenging. He accuses Stephen Farry of a blatantly opportunistic decision to force the college to agree to one of the solutions he proposes for the future streamlining of teacher training in Northern Ireland. original:
The button would give Google Search users the option to purchase without needing to visit a separate website. The company's chief business officer, Omid Kordestani, confirmed the upcoming roll-out of the "Buy Now" button during a conference. This move is seen as a direct response to combat the increasing dominance of Amazon in the online shopping industry.

The "Buy Now" button will aim to streamline the shopping experience for Google users by allowing purchases to be made directly from the search results page. This presents a major shift in Google's strategy, as it transitions from being solely a search engine to a more integrated service provider. 

Google's decision comes after research indicated that many users start their shopping searches on Amazon rather than Google. By implementing this new feature, the tech giant hopes to reclaim some of this lost market share, enhancing customer convenience and boosting its advertising revenues in the process.

While the exact roll-out date remains undisclosed, Google users worldwide anticipate a streamlined and more efficient online shopping experience. With the competition heating up, this could be a game-changer in the e-commerce sphere.

Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan, London Mayor, declared a state of emergency as unprecedented rainfall led to the River Thames bursting its banks, creating chaos in the capital. 

Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan urged residents to follow directives from emergency services and stay away from the affected areas. 

"The safety of Londoners is my top priority. We are doing everything we can to help those affected and prevent further damage," said Khan. 

The London Fire Brigade, along with aid organizations, swiftly responded to the crisis, completing more than 300 rescue missions and delivering essential supplies to stranded residents. 

The flooding has also severely affected transport, with numerous road closures and disruptions in train services. Environmental experts warn that such weather extremes could become more common due to climate change. 

The government has pledged immediate financial support for the affected communities. Recovery and rebuilding efforts are expected to begin as soon as the water levels

original:
The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the government, indicating a stark educational inequality between the two regions.

The research revealed that economically disadvantaged students in the capital are more than twice as likely to achieve good GCSE results compared to their counterparts in northern England. It emerges as a sign of the notable success of the London Challenge Program, initiated in the early 2000s, aimed at improving school performance in the city.

However, this only accentuates the widening educational gap within the country. The IPPR suggested that the government should consider implementing similar initiatives in the north, to improve the quality of education and opportunities for children living in deprived circumstances.

The report also sparked urgent calls for a "Northern Powerhouse" strategy for education, to address the alarming regional disparities and ensure that every child, irrespective of their socio-economic background, has an equal shot at success.

The Republican sought to laugh off the comment, which was preceded by the supporter saying: "We have a problem in this country - it's called misinformation." However, this lightly taken comment has sparked a pivotal discussion across the nation about the dangerous influence of misinformation on public discourse and democratic processes.

As part of the broad political landscape, Republicans, Democrats, and Independents alike are wrestling with the challenge of confronting and correcting falsehoods in a time when unverified news spreads rapidly on social media platforms. Experts argue that this widespread dissemination of misinformation threatens the very fabric of informed citizenry, thus eroding the bedrock of democracy.

In response, tech companies and media outlets are taking steps to combat false news, though progress is slow and rife with controversy. Critics argue that the measures may infringe upon free speech rights. Amid this controversy, the responsibility of distinguishing fact from fiction largely falls on individual citizens, underlining the need for enhanced media literacy in the digital age. Mr Crabb said the relationship with the Welsh government and First Minister Carwyn Jones worked "remarkably well". He said they had been determined that day-to-day politics would not interfere with showing Wales working together. More than 60 world leaders, 4,000 delegates and 1,500 journalists have spent two days at the Celtic Manor Resort for the one of the biggest ever international gatherings ever to be held in the UK. original:
The news agency's account was suspended and it advised all tweets should be ignored until further notice. The false message said: "Breaking: Two world leaders involved in a violent altercation."

With an immediate suspension upon discovery, the agency moved swiftly to prevent further misinformation. A rogue tweet, falsely alleging a violent altercation between two global leaders, was promptly identified and removed. The source of the misleading information is currently under investigation. 

The agency has since issued a formal apology, assuring the public that its top priority is to report accurate, reliable news. The breach has raised questions about the security measures in place and measures are being taken to reinforce protocols. 

The incident has also triggered a broader conversation on the damage caused by false information spread on social media platforms. The impact of such misinformation can be far-reaching, undermining trust and causing unnecessary alarm. 

Upon resolution, the agency plans to learn from this incident, strengthening its security and maintaining its commitment to journalistic integrity. The public is urged to disregard all tweets

original: They spend an average of Â£581 a year on music festivals, often opting for VIP passes or upgraded camping options. Predominantly male, the "superfans" are also more likely than most consumers to buy music on CD or as downloads. The results came from a survey of 504 UK residents, who had attended at least one festival in the last year. According to ticketing website Eventbrite, which commissioned the survey, these "superfans" help to "drive the music festivals market", often recommending music and events to their friends. They account for 28% of the festival-going audience, and more than half of them (54%) say they would be willing to attend an event alone. On average, they spend Â£45 more per event than a casual fan, but their loyalty is not guaranteed: 46% say that festivals are becoming "too corporate". There are more than 100 music festivals held in the UK every year, from the likes of Glastonbury and T In The Park, to smaller events such

original: Among them was a 17-year-old stopped at Sydney airport a fortnight ago, said Immigration Minister Peter Dutton. Mr Dutton said there was a "growing threat" from Australians attempting to join groups like Islamic State (IS). Special anti-terror teams were installed in Australia's eight international airports in August. The teenager, who was on his way to the conflict in the Middle East, was returned to the custody of his parents while investigations continued, said Mr Dutton. The interception came about a week after two Sydney brothers, aged 16 and 17, were stopped at the same airport on suspicion of attempting to join IS. The brothers, who have not been named, were also returned to their parents. According to Australian media reports, the two students have been allowed to resume their studies at a prestigious Sydney high school, despite concerns being raised by some parents of other students at the school. original:
The deal unveiled by Russia on Thursday to set up four "de-escalation zones" is backed by Turkey and Iran. But the main Syrian opposition group rejects the proposal, claiming it lacks credibility and is likely to further militarize and complicate the Syrian conflict. 

The deal unveiled by Russia on Thursday to set up four "de-escalation zones" is backed by Turkey and Iran. But the main Syrian opposition group, the High Negotiations Committee (HNC), voiced strong reservations, stating that the agreement is more likely to freeze the conflict while allowing continued government attacks on opposition-held areas. 

They express their skepticism over the effectiveness of the "de-escalation zones," citing Russia and Iran's track-record of not honoring previous ceasefires. They fear this deal could be an attempt by Moscow to solidify President Bashar al-Assad's control over swathes of Syria. 

In response, Russia insists that the zones will lead to a cessation of hostilities and improve the humanitarian situation. Despite the opposition, Iran and Turkey - who are important regional powers and stakeholders in the Syrian conflict - have shown their support, contributing to the complex

original: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the centre-left think tank in Sheffield. The government said extra funds were being given to early years providers to help children from poorer backgrounds and close the attainment gap. The report has also detailed a number of "tests" or benchmarks for the government's northern powerhouse scheme. Research by the IPPR showed only 47% of children born in the poorest families in the north of England achieved a good level of early years development compared with 59% in London. Its survey also found five northern city-regions combined had almost as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million) - but the IPPR forecasts demand for skilled workers in the North is set to increase. The IPPR has proposed 11 benchmarks for Chancellor George Osborne's flagship policy to boost regional economies, including closing the "stark" gap in the
variant_1: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) reported that London's poorest children performed better than those in northern regions. The centre-left think tank is releasing the report in Sheffield. The government stated that additional funding is being allocated to early years providers to support children from disadvantaged backgrounds and reduce the achievement gap. The report also outlines several benchmarks or "tests" for the government's northern powerhouse initiative. IPPR research found that only 47% of children from the poorest families in northern England reached a good level of early years development, compared to 59% in London. Additionally, the survey revealed that five northern city-regions collectively had nearly as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million), though IPPR predicts rising demand for skilled workers in the North. The IPPR recommended 11 benchmarks for Chancellor George Osborne's key policy aimed at strengthening regional economies, including addressing the significant disparities in achievement.

original: The bodies of backpackers Miss Witheridge, 23, from Norfolk, and Mr Miller, 24, from Jersey, were found on a beach on Koh Tao in September 2014. Burmese bar workers Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Tun were found guilty of the killings in December 2015. An appeal court in Thailand upheld the death sentences handed down to them. Lawyers for the two men now have 30 days to appeal to the Supreme Court - Thailand's final court of appeal. The pair's mothers lodged appeals at Koh Samui court last May over concerns about the judgements, in particular the DNA evidence used in the investigation. "We don't believe the court can say beyond reasonable doubt that Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were responsible for the events which took place in September 2014," said Andy Hall, one of the families' legal advisors. Miss Witheridge, a University of Essex student from Hemsby, and Mr Miller, a civil and structural engineering graduate, were found on a beach

"We don't believe the court can say beyond reasonable doubt that Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were responsible for the events in September 2014," stated Andy Hall, a legal advisor for the families. Miss Witheridge, a University of Essex student from Hemsby, and Mr Miller, a civil and structural engineering graduate, were found on a beach.

The lawyers for these men now have 30 days to appeal to Thailand's Supreme Court, the highest court of appeal. original: Envoy Sigrid Kaag was speaking as Syria appeared to miss a Sunday deadline to remove its arsenal from the country. All Syria's chemical weapons are scheduled to be destroyed by 30 June. The Russian-US deal to eliminate Syria's arsenal was drawn up last year after hundreds of people died in a sarin rocket attack outside Damascus. Destroying Syria's chemical weapons Syria chemical weapons removal plan The multinational mission to get rid of the weapons is overseen by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Although the UN deadline for the total destruction of Syria's chemical weapons is 30 June, Damascus had vowed to complete the removal of its stockpile by 27 April, after missing several deadlines. "The biggest bulk of the chemical weapons material is removed but not yet destroyed and that counts towards the 30 June deadline. That's why it's so important to get the remainder of the chemical weapons material that is still in one site," Ms Kaag, the head of
variant_1: Envoy Sigrid Kaag spoke as Syria seemed to miss a Sunday deadline for removing its chemical weapons from the country. All of Syria's chemical arsenal is planned to be destroyed by June 30. The UN Security Council and the OPCW oversee the multinational mission to dismantle these weapons. original: Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria was surprised to win as he was "struggling" with a chest infection. In his story he "ended up bumping into Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel", he said. "It was a tale about building a small submarine out of my dad's old bubble car," he said. "We took the bubble car on a trip to the Isle of Man and we bumped into several famous people in a Scottish submarine made out of shortbread tins. "Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond sold some of these giant shortbread tin submarines to the United States of America." Last year's winner Mike Naylor, known as Monkey Liar, from Wasdale came second. Helen Jordan came third. Previous winners include comedian and television presenter Sue Perkins in 2006. In 2014 one entrant had travelled from Germany to take part. The annual event is held in front of a panel of judges and an audience at the Bridge Inn at Santon Bridge. Politicians

original: The walkout is in protest over the dismissal of two nurses involved in a violent struggle with a patient. Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton were sacked despite using "reasonable force" against the unidentified patient, said the Prison Officers' Association (POA). But Mersey Care Trust, which runs Ashworth, said the evidence meant sacking the pair was its only option. More on this story and other news from Merseyside and Cheshire The dispute at the unit, one of three high security hospitals in England and Wales, began at 07:00 GMT. Steve Gillan, the POA's general secretary, said: "I believe the general public will be outraged and extremely sympathetic to Mr Hilton and Mr Gregson, who were merely responding to a violent act in which the patient had headbutted a colleague and was spitting at staff during the incident. "The actions of restraint were reasonable and the patient came to no harm, unlike the nurses. Whilst there should always be a duty of care towards patients the same must apply to staff." The trust said it was "disappointed"

Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton were dismissed despite using what the Prison Officers' Association (POA) called "reasonable force" on the unnamed patient. However, Mersey Care Trust, which manages Ashworth, stated that the evidence left no choice but to sack the two. The incident at the unit, one of three high-security hospitals in England and Wales, started at 07:00 GMT. Steve Gillan, the POA general secretary, said the public would be outraged and sympathetic toward Hilton and Gregson, who were reacting to a violent act where the patient headbutted a colleague and spat at staff. He added that the restraint actions were reasonable and the patient was unharmed, unlike the nurses, emphasizing that staff should receive the same duty of care as patients. The trust expressed disappointment.

original: Mr Reagan and three others were injured in the shooting outside a hotel in Washington in March 1981. Mr Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity but was sent for treatment to a Washington hospital. In July, a judge ruled that Mr Hinckley, now 61, was not a danger to himself or the public. Mr Hinckley had already been spending 17 days a month at his mother's home in Virginia under strict conditions. Associated Press reported that he had arrived at her home having been freed on Saturday. Marking 30 years since Reagan's shooting Life after shooting a US president As part of his release he will: The shooting, just weeks into Ronald Reagan's presidency, shocked the world. Mr Reagan was shot in the lung, but recovered. His press secretary James Brady was shot in the head, suffered brain damage and used a wheelchair for the rest of his life. Mr Brady's death in 2014 at the age of 73 was ruled to be a homicide, but no further charges against Hinckley were brought. Two law enforcement officers suffered less

original: He threatened to quit the Premier League club within 24 hours if the name change bid failed, and the Football Association turned it down in April. "When I say something, I mean it," the 75-year-old Egyptian said on Thursday. He added that the club had been put up for sale 22 hours after the FA's decision five months ago. Allam said that an appeal was being lodged against the name change rejection with the Court of Arbitration for Sport. "We stated earlier this year that the club would be for sale should our attempt to globally promote Hull Tigers as a brand name and as a playing name be blocked," he said. "As a consequence of the FA decision on 9 April, I announced on 10 April, within 22 hours, that Hull City is for sale." Allam, who took charge of the club in December 2010, was asked what he would do if a buyer could not be found and the legal appeal was dismissed. "I will give it away. Out

original: The company behind the abattoir in Haverfordwest, Emcol 2008 Ltd, collapsed in January 2016 with debts of £660,000 to more than 230 creditors. One director said it was due to escalating costs and being owed money. Newport dairy farmer John Sollis called it a "disaster" for people in the area who were owed money. Documents lodged on the Companies House website show one livestock trader is owed in excess of £107,000, while others are owed significant five figure sums. In his report, liquidator Gary Stones said any payments to unsecured creditors were "totally dependent on the collection of the Irish book debt". The report indicated almost £470,000 was owed to Emcol by an Irish firm. Mr Sollis, who is owed almost £15,000 by Emcol, said: "It was a disaster in a sense the amount of money that people have lost in the locality and not now having a local abattoir to move stock to or casualties. "Casualties and stock

original: Borrowing the names of organisations like Nasa and the Environmental Protection Agency they are directly attacking the president. Mr Trump has called climate change a hoax. The @RogueNASA account says it is the "unofficial 'Resistance' team of NASA". "Not an official NASA account. Not managed by gov't employees. Come for the facts, stay for the snark," the account declares. BBC News contacted the rogue Environmental Protection Agency account called @ActualEPAFacts. They told us they acted to make sure "factual information about climate change and other scientific research continues to be shared during the Trump administration". They claimed to be three EPA employees and said they acted after a gagging order stopped them from doing interviews relating to their research. Media reports have suggested that the Trump administration sought to limit how certain government agencies - including the EPA - communicate with the public. The official EPA Twitter account has not posted since 19 January, a day before Mr Trump's inauguration. ActualEPAFacts told us they were surprised by how many people are now following their account - more than 90,000 currently - but also felt exposed by

original:
Muslim cleric Mehboob Akhtar, of Stoke-on-Trent, was sentenced along with nine others including his wife and daughter. They were found guilty of a sophisticated benefit fraud scheme, resulting in the embezzlement of over £450,000 of taxpayer’s money. Investigations revealed that the group had submitted fraudulent applications for tax credits and other benefits over a span of five years.

The Stoke Crown Court heard that Akhtar was the mastermind behind the operation that involved his family members and several close friends. Forensic accountants were brought in to unravel the complex web of illegal financial activities, uncovering a calculated and wilful abuse of the system. 

The prosecution said that the money stolen funded a lifestyle far beyond their legitimate means. Despite the severity of the crime, the defendants maintained their innocence throughout the trial. The judge, in his statement, said that their actions were a "deeply regrettable betrayal of trust" and sentenced the group to a combined total of 20 years of imprisonment.

This case serves as a stark reminder of the serious nature of benefit fraud, its impact on society and the dire consequences for those involved

original:
Masai Graham won with the gag: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The winning joke from Masai Graham was crowned the funniest of this year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival. The punchline, "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart," was met with roaring laughter from the audience, securing Graham's victory. 

Graham, a London-based comedian, is known for his sharp wit and dry delivery. Despite fierce competition from seasoned comics, his heart transplant-themed gag stood out, winning over both the audience and the panel of judges.

This win adds to Graham's impressive comedic resume, which already includes several successful appearances at previous fringe festivals. He has shown time and again his ability to turn everyday situations into clever and unexpected punchlines, delighting audiences with his unique comedic style.

The Fringe Festival, held annually in Scotland's capital, is renowned for showcasing the best in comedy talent. This year was no exception, and Graham's win confirms his status as one of the leading lights in the UK comedy scene.

original: The care at Stafford Hospital left some patients drinking water from vases, it is claimed, and receptionists assessing emergency cases. Julie Bailey, who set up the campaign group Cure the NHS after witnessing her mother's treatment, was made a CBE. Helene Donnelly, a nurse who became a whistleblower, was made an OBE. Figures suggested there were more deaths than would have been expected at Stafford Hospital between 2005 and 2008. Patients needing pain relief either got it late or not at all, leaving them crying out for help, and there were cases where food and drinks were left out of reach. Helene Donnelly worked in the A&E department at the hospital. She raised nearly 100 complaints about the treatment of patients, turned whistleblower and was a key witness at the Stafford Hospital public inquiry. She told the BBC she was "tremendously proud and honoured" to receive the OBE for services to the NHS, after what had been a "very difficult time personally and professionally". Ms Donnelly said she was

Donnelly, who worked in A&E, filed nearly 100 complaints, became a whistleblower, and was a key public inquiry witness. She told the BBC she felt "tremendously proud and honoured" to get the OBE after a "very difficult time personally and professionally."

original:
Heading the processions were some of those caught up in the suicide bomb attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station that killed 32 people. Belgian authorities led a solemn march on Thursday, five years after the deadly terror attacks that inflicted deep wounds on the nation's psyche.

Heading the processions were some of those caught up in the suicide bomb attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station that killed 32 people. Belgian officials, survivors, and relatives of the victims came together in a united show of respect and determination to never forget the painful memories of March 22, 2016. The commemoration event started at Zaventem Airport, where two suicide bombers detonated their lethal devices, killing 16 people.

The march then continued to the Maalbeek metro station in central Brussels, where another 16 people were killed when a third bomber detonated his explosives during the morning rush hour. The poignant procession concluded at the heart of the EU district, below the flags of the 28-member bloc – a stark reminder of the indiscriminate nature of terrorism and the unity that binds us in the face of tragedy.

Hibs were hammered 10-1 on aggregate by Bayern Munich, while City lost 3-1 to Eskilstuna United from Sweden, in what has proven to be a disappointing week for British football clubs in the continental leagues. The colossal defeat faced by Hibs, despite their spirited performance, illuminated the glaring gap between British clubs and their European counterparts. Bayern Munich, the German titans, demonstrated their ruthlessness and superior gameplay, leaving the Scottish team in turmoil. 

City, on the other hand, succumbed to a 3-1 defeat to Eskilstuna United. The loss was a bitter pill to swallow for City fans, as hopes were high following their robust performances in domestic leagues. The Swedish team capitalized on City's defensive errors, adding more woes to British football in Europe.

He's also having to get used to the media and laying out his policies - many of which are quite distinct from the previous leader's. Mr. Thomas Granger, the newly appointed leader, is under the spotlight as he outlines his plans for a novel approach to governance.

Granger has already caught the public eye with his efforts to redefine traditional policy structures. His focus on environmental sustainability, economic equity, and digital transformation starkly contrasts his predecessor's conservative approach. Granger's progressive policies have ignited hope in many, while also stirring up controversy among conservatives.

His pledge to reduce carbon emissions by 50% over the next decade has been hailed by environmentalists. Likewise, his commitment to increasing minimum wage and his ambitious plans for digitalising infrastructure have been met with enthusiasm from young voters.

Yet, the new leader isn't without his critics. Many fear his policies might burden the economy. Nonetheless, Granger remains resilient, promising that his policies will drive long-term prosperity.

original: Sales at the company rose to â‚¬34.2bn (Â£28.8bn) in the year to August. The chain opened 12 new stores, which helped total sales to rise 7.1%, but that increase was lower than the 11% growth seen in the previous 12 months. Sales at stores open for more than a year rose 5% - the same as last year. The privately-owned Swedish group said sales in Poland jumped about 20%, making the country its fastest-growing market, while Australia and Canada also performed well. Germany was still the retailer's largest market, closely followed by the United States. Ikea will open its first stores in India and Serbia this year and now has 340 outlets in 28 countries. However, expansion into Russia has been put on hold as Ikea seeks to solve "a number of old legal disputes". The chain has 19 stores in the UK, with new outlets planned for Exeter,

The European Challenge Tour event will be part of a big week in the season with both the US PGA Championship and Women's British Open also taking place. The European Challenge Tour, known for unearthing golf's up-and-coming stars, is set to be a highlight of an already action-packed week, which also includes the US PGA Championship and the Women's British Open.

The Challenge Tour event is a prestigious platform for young talents to showcase their skills, often serving as a stepping stone to greater heights in the world of professional golf. With the PGA Championship and the Women's British Open occurring simultaneously, the week promises to offer golf enthusiasts a thrilling spectacle from established pros to rising stars.

The US PGA Championship, one of golf's four major tournaments, brings together the top golfers from around the world. Amidst the excitement, the Women's British Open, another major, will keep fans engaged with some of the best female golfers battling for the championship.

In this busy and exciting week for golf, the European Challenge Tour event stands as an opportunity for new talents to make their mark and for golf aficionados to catch a glimpse of the

original:
The cut, which took the markets by surprise, was the first since 2012, and comes into effect on Saturday. The one-year lending rate has been slashed by a significant percentage as part of a series of measures to boost a slowing economy. Economists predict this bold move may trigger a slew of similar cuts across the globe, potentially heralding a new era of competitive interest rate reductions.

The decision, announced by the Central Bank on Friday, is widely seen as a response to persistent low inflation and weaker-than-expected growth figures. The Bank said the move aims to "ensure the stability of the financial system and foster sustainable economic growth."

Market watchers believe the surprise rate cut could serve as a strong stimulus for the struggling economy, providing much-needed liquidity and encouraging borrowing. The move is expected to boost business confidence and spur investment, which could in turn lead to job creation and increased consumer spending, further stimulating economic growth. However, some analysts caution that the decision could also lead to increased financial risk

original: The 23-year-old Heracles forward claimed he was waiting to finalise a move to the Championship club. Slade insisted there was no truth to the reports but admitted he did have some interest in the player "some time ago". "To my knowledge that's not something we're going to pursue," he said. Netherlands Under-21 international Weghorst began his career with FC Emmen before joining Heracles in 2014. Heracles chairman Jam Smit believed a fee had been agreed with Cardiff for Weghorst, who has also been linked with Celtic. "I think all the forcing and all the speculation surrounding the player appears to be have come from the Netherlands," added Slade. "There was an initial inquiry some time ago. That's all I can say." original: Falcon and Pointer was fined £175,000 for making automated calls about PPI, and Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was fined £50,000 for asking to speak to people's dead relatives. Both companies claimed the calls were made by a third party. Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, said it sent a "clear message to callous cold-callers". She said: "It increasingly appears from our investigations that Swansea is the UK's cold-call capital. "Companies in the city have been trying to cash in using ruthless business models based on illicit practices to make calls which are at best irksome and at worst distressing." The commissioner (ICO) has taken action against six companies since 2013. Falcon and Pointer had its licence revoked in January 2016 and told the ICO it had stopped making the calls in June 2015 - but an investigation found it made a further two million calls in the following two months. Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd, which sells windows, doors and conservatories, received 168 complaints in six

Both blamed third-party callers. Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, said this sends a strong warning to ruthless cold-callers. She noted Swansea seems to be the UK's cold-call hotspot, with companies exploiting unethical tactics to make annoying or distressing calls. Since 2013, the ICO has acted against six firms. Falcon and Pointer lost its licence in January 2016 and claimed to have ceased calls in June 2015, but an investigation revealed two million more calls afterward. Direct Choice Home Improvements, selling windows and conservatories, got 168 complaints in six months.

original:
The Employment and Learning minister, Dr Stephen Farry, has decided to remove a special premium payment of Â£1.1m which it has been annually disbursed to Northern Ireland's universities. The special premium, usually reserved for science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) courses, has been described by Dr Farry as a "disincentive for universities to broaden their curriculum."

This decision arrives amidst a backdrop of continuing funding issues and budget concerns plaguing the higher education sector in Northern Ireland. The minister hopes the removal of this premium will encourage universities to diversify their course offerings, particularly in the arts and humanities.

Critics of Dr Farry's decision argue it could inadvertently damage the prospects of STEM students, whose subjects are often more costly to deliver. However, Dr Farry insists that the general block grant for universities will not be affected and that the institutions would still have sufficient resources to maintain and invest in STEM courses.

The move is consistent with the minister’s previous insistence on a more balanced higher education sector. Whether the change will bring the desired effect in broadening the curriculum remains to be seen.

This premium, typically allocated for STEM courses, was called a "disincentive for universities to broaden their curriculum" by Dr Farry.

original: The amnesty applies to offences committed during the political turmoil after Mr Thaksin was ousted in a coup. The lower house passed the controversial bill in the early hours of Friday. It now goes to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has warned that the passage of the bill will trigger street protests. It did not take part in the vote, but the bill passed by 310 votes to 0. The bill's passage through the Senate is less certain, reports the BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, as half its members are appointed. But this could happen as early as next week and would almost certainly provoke further protests. Advocates of the bill say it will draw a line under the political turmoil that resulted from the military coup in 2006 that removed Mr Thaksin from power, leaving Thailand bitterly divided. This turmoil included the occupation of Bangkok's main airport in 2008 and then two months of street protests in Bangkok in
variant_1: The amnesty covers crimes committed during the political unrest following Mr. Thaksin's ousting in a coup. The lower house approved the contentious bill in the early hours of Friday, and it now moves to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has warned that the bill's approval will spark street protests. The party abstained from voting, yet the bill passed 310 to 0. The Senate's approval is less certain, according to BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, since half of its members are appointed. However, it could be approved as soon as next week, likely provoking more protests. Supporters say the bill will close the chapter on the political unrest caused by the 2006 military coup that removed Mr. Thaksin, leaving Thailand deeply divided. This unrest included the 2008 occupation of Bangkok's main airport and two months of street protests in Bangkok.
variant_2: The amnesty pertains to offenses committed amid the political upheaval after Mr. Thaksin was removed in a coup. They did not participate in the vote, but the bill passed unanimously with 310 votes. The Senate's approval is uncertain, according to BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, as half the Senate members are appointed. Yet, it might be approved as soon as next week, likely sparking further protests. Proponents argue the bill will end the political turmoil triggered by the 2006 military coup that ousted Mr. Thaksin, which left Thailand deeply divided. This turmoil included the 2008 occupation of Bangkok's main airport and a two-month protest in Bangkok.

Supporters say the bill will close the chapter on the political turmoil resulting from the 2006 military coup that removed Mr. Thaksin, which left Thailand bitterly divided. This turmoil included the 2008 occupation of Bangkok's main airport and two months of protests in Bangkok.

South Korea's 140-tonne rocket, known as Naro, was built in partnership with Russia, which had agreed to work with Seoul for three launch attempts. original: Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site is made up of some 40,000 large black basalt columns which protrude from the sea. It was the Royal couple's first visit to Northern Ireland's best known tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced up through fissures in the earth to form a lava plateau. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh then travelled to the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg. He won a Victoria Cross for bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg was given the highest military award for valour after going out into the line of fire to search for his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh unveiled a statue of the soldier as well as a commemorative stone. His grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, also gave a short address. From there, the Royal couple moved on to a reception at Portrush Golf Club as guests of

The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August. No one was injured in the incident, but it sparked major concerns about the potential catastrophic risks that drones could pose to commercial flights. 

The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August. No immediate damage was reported, but air traffic controllers were alerted about the potential hazard. The drone, estimated to be about a meter across, was flying well above the legal altitude limit for unmanned aircraft, at an estimated height of 4,000 feet.

The incident reignited urgent conversations about regulations surrounding drone use, especially the need for stricter enforcement and harsher penalties for those who flout these rules. The Civil Aviation Authority reiterated the importance of responsible drone use, warning drone operators to stick to the designated height and distance limits. The disturbing near-miss underscores the urgent need for comprehensive action to ensure the safe coexistence of drones and manned aircraft in our increasingly crowded skies.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Monday amid the ongoing fuel crisis. This social media trend saw internet users recasting famous movie scenes in the context of the country's fuel shortage, blending humor and frustration.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm sparked hundreds of thousands of tweets, reflecting the French public's concern and exasperation over the energy crisis. Twitter users cleverly inserted the issue into famous scenes from films like Mad Max, Titanic, and Back to the Future. One humorous tweet suggested a reimagined Pulp Fiction where John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson's characters argue over who must push their out-of-gas car.

While the hashtag speaks to the French's knack for humor in crises, it underscores a pressing issue. France has been grappling with fuel shortages due to strikes at oil refineries and blockades protesting against government policies. This virtual outcry reflects the public's call for effective solutions to the country's escalating fuel crisis.

Midfielder Arteta, 32, had a bony spur removed from his left ankle, which the club said has been causing him "significant discomfort" throughout the past season. The surgery, performed by renowned orthopedic surgeon Dr. Richard Smith, was deemed a success and has been hailed as a positive step forward for the veteran player's future performance.

Arteta's career has been marked by exceptional ball handling and creative playmaking, earning him a loyal fan base. The ankle issue had been a setback, but it has not dented his determination. The player's representatives have confirmed that he is already keen to start rehabilitation.

The club's medical staff is optimistic about his recovery process, predicting that his return to the pitch could be as soon as the next season. Fans are eagerly anticipating his comeback, hoping that a fully fit Arteta can help lead the team to victory.

The successful operation underscores the importance of addressing physical issues promptly for athletes, ensuring that they can continue to perform at

original:
A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than "A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than two weeks off to spend time with their newborns, suggesting that workplace cultures and policies may pose a critical barrier to parental involvement in early child care.

The survey, which involved over 1,000 participants across various job sectors, reflected a persistent stigma associated with paternity leave. Many new fathers reported feeling pressured to return to work due to concerns about job security, income stability, and perceptions of traditional gender roles.

The findings highlight a need for a paradigm shift in corporate attitudes towards paternity leave. Experts argue that encouraging fathers to take their full leave can have significant benefits, not only for the child's development and the mother's postpartum recovery but also for the overall productivity and morale of employees. It's time for businesses to reassess their policies and culture and contribute proactively to nurturing an equitable workforce.
variant_1: A survey of employees and managers revealed that 25% of new fathers did not take any paternity leave. Less than 10% took more than two weeks off to care for their newborns, indicating that workplace culture and policies may hinder early parental involvement.
variant_2: According to a survey of employees and managers, one in four new fathers took no paternity leave, and fewer than 10% took over two weeks off, suggesting that workplace norms and policies could be a major obstacle to early child care participation.
variant_3: The survey, which included over 1,000 workers from various sectors, found that a quarter of new dads skipped paternity leave entirely, while under 10% took more than two weeks, pointing to cultural and policy barriers in workplaces.

original: Sterling rose 1.86% against the dollar to $1.32.40, and was 1.73% higher against the euro at â‚¬1.19.57. The FTSE 100 share index hit fresh 11-month highs before falling back and closing scarcely changed at 6,680.69, that is a slight fall of 2.17 points or 0.03%. The more UK-focused FTSE 250 index rose 68.75 points, or 0.4%, to 16,775.14. The property sector - which saw a steep sell-off immediately after the Brexit vote - received a boost from Galliford Try. The housebuilder said it still expected full-year profits to be in line with expectations sending its shares up 8.5%. Financial stocks - another victim of the post-referendum sell-off - were also having a better day. Shares in insurer Aviva rose 4.26% while Lloyds Banking Group gained 2.55%. "Theresa May's virtual 'coronation' as prime minister has delivered a boost to the pound as the clouds of uncertainty following the Brexit vote start to disperse," said Neil Wilson,

original: Evha Jannath, 11, was on a school trip on Tuesday when she fell from a circular boat on Splash Canyon at Drayton Manor. Alton Towers and Legoland Windsor are among those to have closed similar water-based white knuckle rides. Drayton Manor said it would remain closed on Friday for health and safety investigations. Latest on this and other stories from Staffordshire Merlin Entertainments, which runs Legoland and Alton Towers, said it had closed the following rides: A spokesperson said that on learning of Tuesday's fatal fall at Drayton Manor, Merlin Entertainments shut the rides "with immediate effect" on a "precautionary basis". It said it expected to re-open the rides on Friday. Some sites, including Lightwater Valley, in North Yorkshire, and West Midland Safari Park, have not closed rides in response to the death at Drayton Manor. A safari park spokesman said it had, however, introduced a policy whereby all children need to be accompanied by an adult on its water rides. The Halle Orchestra wants to open a school in Stoke-on-Trent in 2020, for both primary and secondary pupils. The orchestra, known for its renowned musical heritage, is taking this bold step to nurture a new generation of musicians.

The proposed school will be a first-of-its-kind initiative in the region, offering a unique curriculum integrating classical music education with standard academics. The Halle Orchestra aims to provide a platform for youngsters to pursue their passion for music in a formal setting, while also ensuring they excel in other academic areas.

The school plans to have experienced musicians from the orchestra as trainers and mentors for the students. This will give students the rare opportunity to learn directly from professionals who are part of one of the UK's oldest and most respected symphony orchestras.

The investment is backed by nearly £15m from the Welsh government, with production due to start in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart said the funding is part of an ambitious project aiming to boost the region's economy and create new job opportunities. This investment will channel into the manufacturing sector, which is earmarked as a key growth area. 

Hart emphasized the importance of the manufacturing industry, stating it contributes significantly to the Welsh economy. She believes this investment is a testament to the government's commitment to promote economic growth, sustainability and job creation.

The funds are expected to attract more businesses to the region, further stimulating the local economy. Hart expressed hopes that such a significant investment would send a clear message to businesses across the UK and beyond about Wales' readiness for economic development.

This initiative forms part of the Welsh government's broader strategy to strengthen the economy, enhance job opportunities, and improve living standards across the region.

original: The Swiss bank said US regulators were investigating potential sales of so called "bearer bonds". These bonds can be transferred without registering ownership, enabling wealthy clients to potentially hide assets. "We are cooperating with the authorities in these investigations," the bank said. The fresh investigation by the US Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York and from the US Securities and Exchange Commission comes after UBS paid $780m (Â£512m) in 2009 to settle a separate Justice Department tax-evasion probe. And it comes as authorities in a range of countries are considering examining HSBC's actions in helping more than 100,000 wealthy individuals avoid paying tax. UBS made the announcement as it revealed a better-than-expected 13% rise in fourth quarter net profit to 963m Swiss francs (Â£683.9m). However, it warned the increased value of the Swiss franc relative to other currencies, following the Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon the cap on the currency's value against the euro, would "put pressure" on its profitability. "The increased value of the Swiss franc relative to other currencies, especially the US dollar and the euro, and negative interest

The Black Caps, having been set a world record 504 to win, resumed on 142-3 and their challenge quickly folded. Brendon McCullum, their captain, despite his best efforts, couldn't turn the tide as the rest of the team struggled to cope up with the pressure. 

The bowling attack led by formidable names from the opposition had made the Caps' chase a Herculean task. McCullum started off the day with some hope, but it was soon extinguished as wickets fell like dominos around him. The audience watched in dismay as their team failed to seize control of the game.

The New Zealand team's underperformance on this day will be a significant blow to their World Cup campaign. However, the Black Caps have always been known for their fighting spirit. This defeat, however serious, may not break their resolve. The cricket world will be keenly watching how the Black Caps bounce back from this setback. With their ability to surprise and conquer, a

original: The company said it had been cleared by government officials in Senegal to launch an evaluation plan. Cairn, which made two discoveries in the area last year, estimated fields there could contain more than a billion barrels of oil. Its evaluation plan will start shortly with a 3D seismic survey. Later this year it aims to launch a multi-well exploration and appraisal programme. Edinburgh-based Cairn has a 40% interest in three blocks offshore Senegal (Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, Rufisque Offshore). Its partners include ConocoPhillips (35%) and FAR Ltd (15%), with Petrosen, the Senegal National Oil Company, retaining a 10% interest in the exploration phase. In its latest half-yearly report, Cairn also said that it had started international arbitration proceedings with the government of India over a tax row. Cairn has been prevented by Indian authorities from accessing the value of its 10% residual shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). In March, the company received a tax bill for $1.6bn plus interest and penalties, covering the
variant_1: The company announced that it has received approval from Senegalese government officials to initiate an evaluation plan. Cairn, which discovered two sites in the region last year, estimates that the fields may hold over a billion barrels of oil. The evaluation will begin soon with a 3D seismic survey, followed later this year by a multi-well exploration and appraisal program. Cairn, based in Edinburgh, holds a 40% stake in three offshore Senegal blocks (Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, Rufisque Offshore). Its partners are ConocoPhillips (35%) and FAR Ltd (15%), while Petrosen, Senegal's national oil company, keeps a 10% interest during exploration. In its recent half-year report, Cairn revealed it initiated international arbitration against the Indian government over a tax dispute. Indian authorities have blocked Cairn from accessing the value of its 10% residual shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). In March, Cairn was issued a tax demand of $1.6 billion plus interest and penalties.
variant_2: According to the company, government officials in Senegal have authorized it to proceed with an evaluation plan. Cairn, which made two discoveries in the area last year, believes the fields could hold more than a billion barrels of oil. The evaluation will commence shortly with a 3D seismic survey, with plans to launch a multi-well exploration and appraisal program later this year. Edinburgh-based Cairn owns 40% of three offshore Senegal blocks—Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, and Rufisque Offshore. Its partners include ConocoPhillips (35%) and FAR Ltd (15%), while Petrosen, the Senegal National Oil Company, retains a 10% stake during exploration. In its latest semi-annual report, Cairn also disclosed it has started international arbitration with the Indian government over a tax dispute. Indian authorities have prevented Cairn from accessing its 10% residual shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). In March, the company received a tax bill amounting to $1.6 billion plus interest and penalties.

original: Muslim cleric Mehboob Akhtar, of Stoke-on-Trent, was sentenced along with nine others including his wife and daughter. They were found guilty of lying to mortgage lenders to amass nearly Â£1m of property in a bid to "control and dominate" areas of the city. Akhtar was jailed for 14 years at Birmingham Crown Court. Read more updates on this story and more from across Stoke and Staffordshire Following a trial last month, the 60-year-old, of Farman Close in Fenton, was convicted of 11 charges including five of conspiracy to commit fraud and cheating Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC) out of Â£271,000. The court heard how Akhtar, who was also known as Saint Pirwali Pandariman, masterminded the conspiracy over more than a decade, between 2003 and 2014. Originally from Pakistan, he was a prominent faith leader in Fenton and helped raise several million pounds in donations to fight poverty through the area's Darbar Unique Centre, the court heard. But judge Stephen Eyre said he had "let down his followers". He said: "[You used] the prestige and devotion of others to facilitate this offending. "Your role
variant_1: Mehboob Akhtar, a Muslim cleric from Stoke-on-Trent, was sentenced alongside nine others, including his wife and daughter, after being found guilty of deceiving mortgage lenders to acquire nearly £1 million in property to "control and dominate" parts of the city. Akhtar received a 14-year prison sentence at Birmingham Crown Court. Following a trial last month, the 60-year-old from Farman Close in Fenton was convicted on 11 counts, including five for conspiracy to commit fraud and cheating HMRC out of £271,000. The court revealed that Akhtar, also known as Saint Pirwali Pandariman, orchestrated the scheme over more than ten years, from 2003 to 2014. Originally from Pakistan, he was a respected faith leader in Fenton and raised millions for poverty relief through the Darbar Unique Centre. original: The country's Chamber of Deputies had already approved the legislation. The vote in the Senate, which backed the bill by just six votes, came after 14 hours of at times heated debate. The law, which also allows same-sex couples to adopt, had met with fierce opposition from the Catholic Church and other religious groups. The legislation, backed by President Cristina Fernandez's centre-left government, passed by 33 votes to 27 with three abstentions. Outside Congress, as the debate continued into the early hours of Thursday, supporters and opponents of the bill held rival demonstrations. "Nearly every political and social figure has spoken out in favour of marriage equality," said Maria Rachid, president of the Argentine Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transsexuals. "And we hope that the Senate reflects this and that Argentina, from today forward, is a more just country for all families," she told the Associated Press. Your commentsQ&A: Argentina gay marriage law Ines Frank, from a group called Argentine
variant_1: The country's Chamber of Deputies had already passed the legislation. The Senate vote, which supported the bill by a narrow margin of six votes, followed 14 hours of sometimes intense debate. The law, which permits same-sex couples to adopt, faced strong opposition from the Catholic Church and other religious groups. Supported by President Cristina Fernandez's centre-left government, the legislation passed with 33 votes in favor, 27 against, and three abstentions. Outside Congress, as the debate extended into early Thursday morning, supporters and opponents of the bill held competing demonstrations. "Almost every political and social leader has expressed support for marriage equality," said Maria Rachid, president of the Argentine Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transsexuals. "We hope the Senate will reflect this and that Argentina will become a fairer country for all families starting today," she told the Associated Press. original:
The removal of the engines, which have lain idle for two years, would leave 142 active vehicles in the capital. Savings from the proposal would amount to approximately $2 million annually, a considerable injection into the city's economy. The municipality's plan is to recycle these engines and parts for other uses, aiming to promote a more sustainable city model.

This decision follows the city's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote an eco-friendly transportation system. The fleet's reduction has raised concerns among certain groups, which argue that it could lead to delays in public services. Despite this, the city council insists it's an essential move towards sustainability and efficient resource management.

The savings will be redirected to enhance public transportation services and infrastructure, which is expected to benefit around 700,000 daily commuters. The city council believes this plan will not only benefit the environment but also promote a healthier lifestyle among residents. The removal is set to commence next month.
